statement.text: Both EVAR and open repair are effective treatments for AAA. EVAR has lower perioperative mortality (1-2% vs 4-5%) but requires lifelong surveillance and has higher reintervention rates. Open repair has higher upfront risk but better durability. Choice depends on anatomy (EVAR requires suitable neck/iliac), patient fitness, and life expectancy.
statement.formal: EVAR: 30-day mortality 1-2% | Reintervention 20-30% at 5 years | Requires surveillance | Open: 30-day mortality 4-5% | Reintervention 5-10% at 5 years | No surveillance | Selection: Anatomy + Fitness + Life expectancy

explanation.intuition: Think of it as fixing a leaky pipe. EVAR is like inserting a sleeve from inside - less invasive, faster recovery, but you need the right pipe shape and must check it regularly. Open repair is like cutting the wall, replacing the pipe, and patching it up - bigger operation, longer recovery, but the fix is more permanent. Young, fit patients may be better served by getting open repair done once, while older or sicker patients benefit from the easier recovery of EVAR even if they need follow-up.
explanation.key_insight: The early survival advantage of EVAR disappears over time. By 8-10 years, survival curves converge because EVAR patients have ongoing aneurysm-related deaths (rupture from endoleak, reintervention complications). For patients with >10-year life expectancy, open repair may be the better choice if they can tolerate it.
explanation.technical_details: Key trials: EVAR-1 and DREAM showed lower 30-day mortality for EVAR but no long-term survival benefit. OVER trial showed equivalent 9-year survival. EVAR requires: (1) Adequate proximal neck (≥10-15 mm length, ≤30-32 mm diameter, <60° angulation); (2) Suitable iliac access (≥7 mm diameter, <90° tortuosity); (3) Adequate distal landing zones. Open repair indications: Young/fit patients, EVAR-ineligible anatomy, connective tissue disease, mycotic/inflammatory aneurysm, need for concomitant renal/mesenteric revascularization.
common_misconceptions: EVAR is always better because it's less invasive - long-term outcomes are similar
Open repair is outdated - it remains the gold standard for durability
All AAAs are suitable for EVAR - 30-40% have unfavorable anatomy
Surveillance after EVAR is optional - it's mandatory and lifelong

definitions_glossary.evar: Endovascular Aortic Repair - stent-graft placement via femoral access
definitions_glossary.open_repair: Traditional surgery with aortic clamping and graft interposition
definitions_glossary.proximal_neck: Normal aorta between renal arteries and aneurysm
definitions_glossary.reintervention: Additional procedures to address complications or failures
definitions_glossary.surveillance: Regular imaging follow-up to detect complications

open_repair_preferred: Young/fit patients with long life expectancy

definition.@value: Comparison of endovascular and open surgical approaches for AAA repair

sources.citation: OVER Trial. N Engl J Med. 2019;380:2126-2135.

learning_objectives: Compare perioperative and long-term outcomes of EVAR vs open repair
Identify patient factors favoring each approach
Understand the importance of shared decision-making
clinical_pearls: EVAR wins early (less perioperative mortality), open wins late (fewer reinterventions)
Long-term survival is similar - choose based on patient factors
~30-40% of patients are not anatomic candidates for EVAR
EVAR without lifelong surveillance is dangerous
